awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding Reactivity in American Native Impacted Uranium Mines (URANIUM): Research, Education and Outreach
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Cerrato
Proposal: 1652619

The goal of this project is to identify governing biogeochemical mechanisms affecting the contamination and remediation of metals in organic-rich sediments in abandoned uranium (U) mine wastes in northwest and central New Mexico. Abandoned mine waste sites, many of which are located in Native American communities, remain inadequately managed in the United States; the occurrence and mobility of metals in such communities are poorly understood. Mine wastes can be used as sources of scarce precious metals for modern societal demands. Results from this project will help guide reclamation strategies with recovered materials potentially benefiting affected communities. Partnership with Native American communities in New Mexico will facilitate information exchange, access to sites, and collaborative training opportunities for students.

The PI will investigate changes in U speciation and accumulation in organic-rich sediments by integrating ex-situ and in-situ spectroscopy, microscopy, and synchrotron-based real-time experiments. This fundamental knowledge will open new possibilities for future reclamation strategies to integrate remediation with metal recovery processing from mine wastes using local resources. The research objectives of this project are to: 1) quantify the dissolution rate of U-organic matter, uranium-phosphorus (U-P), uranium-vanadium (U-V), and U-oxide bearing minerals from abandoned mine wastes after exposure to surface oxidizing laboratory conditions; 2) determine how the interfacial interaction between aqueous U and organic-rich sediments affects U redox and binding with organic matter functional groups in solids by integrating X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), synchrotron based real time X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and aqueous chemistry measurements; and 3) identify the governing mechanisms that affect the accumulation of U in plants at the interface of water and organic-rich sediments. The education objectives are to: 1) develop an educational approach to effectively communicate scientific outcomes related to potential health hazards associated with metals present in abandoned mine wastes to Native American communities; 2) develop a training program to increase participation and empowerment of Native American students to engage in Environmental Science and Engineering; and 3) present relevant scientific activities and findings of the URANIUM project at the New Mexico Museum for Natural History & Science to raise awareness of the legacy of abandoned mine wastes for K-12 students and general audiences. The outcomes of this project will directly impact Native American communities in New Mexico and have implications for other sites worldwide confronting the legacy of abandoned mine wastes.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to integrate research, outreach, and education activities for the identification of biogeochemical reaction mechanisms between uranium (U) and natural organic matter (NOM) in abandoned mine wastes located in New Mexico. Various abandoned mine waste sites have not been adequately reclaimed or remediated in Native American communities, representing a significant societal challenge. Major knowledge gaps have hampered our understanding of the interaction of uranium and organic matter in natural geologic deposits which contain mixtures of various elements in complex settings. Understanding these processes is essential for the development of adequate remediation strategies.

 

The intellectual merit of this research relates to the advancement of our understanding of reactions between U and NOM relevant to mineralized deposits. We identified the influence of pH on organic functional chemistry of NOM and U speciation in mineralized deposits. Batch experiments were conducted reacting solids from mineralized deposits with solutions at pH 13, 7, and 2. Our results from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses indicate that phenolic and carbonyl functional groups were more abundant than carboxylic groups in sample supernatants. Phenolic functional groups were the most sensitive to changes in pH in these experiments. Results from X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) indicate that mixtures of reduced U(IV) and oxidized U(VI) were detected in solid samples and supernatants from these experiments. These results provide insights about the mobility of U in natural mineralized deposits.

 

Our research also identified U(VI) precipitation by NOM at low pH which may be relevant to the formation of mineralized deposits other U and organic-rich environmental systems such as radioactive waste repositories, and wetlands. The oxidized form of U, U(VI), is predominant in surface oxic conditions found in mine waste sites. Spectroscopic analyses of reacted solids from batch experiments indicate that U(VI) is mainly adsorbed to particulate organic matter at pH 4. However, nanocrystalline solids containing U(VI) were identified at pH 4 by transmission electron microscopy. Our results indicate that precipitation reactions affect the solubility of U(VI) and NOM in natural and anthropogenic water systems at acidic pH.

 

This project also contributed to the advancement of our knowledge about the co-occurrence of uranium with vanadium, arsenic, and other metals in mine waste solids. Our work provides solubility constants and other thermodynamic information for uranyl vanadate solids and uranyl arsenate solids. Additionally, we provide kinetic information about the dissolution or uranyl vanadate and uranyl arsenate solids. This information is useful for reactive transport models that can be applied toward the development of risk assessment and remediation strategies in mine waste sites.

 

This project also identified the uptake of U in plants. Our results indicate that calcium in water containing carbonate at circumneutral pH facilitates the transport of U(VI) in plant roots. We also identified the entrapment of uranium?phosphorus nanocrystals inside root cells of plants from a mine site in New Mexico. Our research indicates that the uptake of U in the roots of plants is mediated by complexation of U with organic functional groups in the cell wall, and that precipitation reactions result in the formation of U-phosphate nano-crystals in the root cells. This information is relevant for bioremediation strategies for uranium in mine waste sites.

 

Broader impacts of our research include community dialogue meetings to discuss mining legacy issues in the Pueblo of Laguna. These activities were conducted in collaboration with the Southwest Research and Information Center which helped inform our research and develop strategies to communicate our results with our partner community members. Additionally, we collaborated with the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science (NMMNHS) education staff to plan educational programming and exhibitions targeted for general public audiences. This research supported 2 PhD students, 1 Master student and 2 undergraduate student researchers from under-represented minority backgrounds.
